text: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to reduce pain, fever, and inflammation. Long-term or excessive use may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, kidney damage, and cardiovascular events.

Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is commonly used for pain relief and fever. Excessive dosage can cause severe liver toxicity. Alcohol consumption increases the risk of liver damage when taken with paracetamol.
Antibiotics are effective against bacterial infections but do not treat viral infections such as the common cold or influenza. Misuse of antibiotics contributes to antimicrobial resistance.
Aspirin is an antiplatelet medication used to reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke. It may cause gastric irritation and bleeding, especially in patients with a history of ulcers.
Combining benzodiazepines with opioids can increase the risk of respiratory depression, coma, and death. Such combinations should only be used under strict medical supervision.
